description.narrative: After more than three decades of multiparty rule and youth demography advantages, Mozambique still struggles to address deficits of effective youth political participation. The Mozambican parliament currently has few Members of Parliament (MPs) under the age of 35 and although all parliamentary parties have active youth wings and quotas for youth, their voices are often not heard in critical debates. From the previous legislature to the current legislature, the representation of young people in parliament has decreased from 40 to 17 people.

The project Academy for Young Politicians will strengthen the knowledge, skills and capacities of young leaders of political parties’ leagues through a comprehensive training program of democracy schools, in order to enhance quantitative and qualitative youth representation in parliament and other representation structures. To build capacities and resources for effective political participation of young politicians on the consolidation of Mozambican multiparty democracy through training, dialogue and collaborative work. 1) Improve capacity of young politicians, youth leagues and civic activists and, hence the overall political party to engage in political processes. 2) Foster dialogue and connection among young politicians, civil society and local authorities across the political divide.
The project's target group are young people between 18 and 35 years of age.
